sources.full: Finding your Path in the Krosmoz

entries.name: Unaligned Deities
entries: The gods in the World of Twelve are fickle and ever-changing. Be it due to their grand plans, capricious personality or reincarnating nature, most gods can fit any alignment. As long as mortals do not disrespect them or interfere with their plans, they also do not have any disregard towards their faithful's alignment.
If any spell or effect requires you to choose an alignment your unaligned deity has, you instead choose from your own alignment.

trait.name: Xelor
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Xelor|FPKrosmoz|Xelor's Sandglass}. {@ancestry Xelor|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Sram
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Sram|FPKrosmoz|Sram's Shadow}. {@ancestry Sram|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Eniripsa
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Eniripsa|FPKrosmoz|Eniripsa's Hands}. {@ancestry Eniripsa|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Meticulous
entries: This weapon is ideal to attack an enemy's weak points. On a critical hit, the weapon adds a precision damage die of the listed size. Roll this after doubling the weapon's damage. This increases to two dice if the weapon has a {@item greater striking} rune and three dice if the weapon has a {@item major striking} rune. For instance, a {@item rapier} with a {@item greater striking} rune deals {@damage 2d8} extra precision damage on a critical hit. An ability that changes the size of the weapon's normal damage dice doesn't change the size of its meticulous die.

trait.name: Sacrier
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Sacrier|FPKrosmoz|Sacrier's Blood}. {@ancestry Sacrier|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Ragged
entries: This weapon's edge is uneven with the specific purpose of drawing more blood. When you hit a creature, this weapon deals 1 additional alignment damage per weapon damage die.

trait.name: Cra
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Cra|FPKrosmoz|Cra's Range}. {@ancestry Cra|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Beacon
entries: A special Cra mechanism activated by attacking it, usually with ranged weaponry. Bombs with this trait are thrown at terrain instead of creatures and don't deal damage until activated with a {@action Strike} targeting the beacon bomb or by otherwise damaging it. If the beacon is thrown but not activated, you can recover it as an {@action Interact} action.

trait.name: Iop
entries: A creature with this trait is a member of the {@ancestry Iop|FPKrosmoz|Iop's Heart}. {@ancestry Iop|FPKrosmoz} craft and use these weapons.

trait.name: Compulsion
entries: This weapon can channel your deity's favour. When you hit a creature of opposite alignment to you, this weapon deals 1 additional alignment damage per weapon damage die as appropriate for your alignment (for example, if you are good, you deal good damage, and if you are evil, you deal evil damage). If multiple alignments are applicable, you choose one of them.

ancestry.name: Iop
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).
info: One thing's for sure: you can't change a Iop! Once you appreciate this and are fully aware of it, you will get along with them much better. To be more efficient and gain time, some Iops reduce their vocabulary to about twenty words, which is enough for their daily needs: eat, drink, sleep, and fight. Eat again, drink again, sleep again and fight again... eat some more, drink some more and fight some more. They do know how to use their weapons, though, and that's enough to keep them happy. To give them some credit, they have a great range of insults that they tend to use when fighting: scabby Gobbly, Larva liver, Bloplicker, Trool droppings and so on. And all in all, Iops simply love their lives!

Their impetuous moods make Iops extreme warriors, capable of the worst as well as the best. Some Iops, such as the knight Rish Claymore, are famous for their strength and bravery. Others delight in violence and barbarity and have written their names in bloody letters on the wall of the World's history: Eratz the Protester might be the best example.

items: Eagerly meet any chance to prove your strength in a physical contest.
View dying in glorious combat as preferable to a mundane death from old age or illness.
Fight tooth and nail—sometimes literally—to protect yourself and your friends from danger.
Assume you can't—or won't—read.
See you as violent or lacking in discipline.
Recognize your incredible endurance and dedication.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Iop tend to be tall and well-built. Even if an Iop seems lanky, they are likely to pack a punch! Their pupils tend to be of a very light colour, sometimes even as far as seeming to have entirely white eyes, and their face distinctly lacks a nose. Their hair is often long and spiky, and of a bright orange colour. Most Iops stand as tall as 6 feet from their feet to the top of their heads. An Iop's hair adds some extra height, with most hairstyles growing vertically as tall as one foot. Not all Iop hairstyles grow as vertically, however, and some Iops instead have hair that flops down behind their head.

Iops age at a similar rate to normal humans. Most Iops can live to be up to 80 years of age, but the more powerful Iops could live for nearly two centuries. Iops weigh the same as normal humans of similar well-built physiques. Iops typically wear long tunics, though they are comfortable in any clothing they can easily fight in. Crosses are also often depicted on their clothing.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Iops often take on the jobs that require more brawn than brain. All Iops may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Most of them will show a great deal of respect towards any great warrior, and notably towards high officials in the Temple of Iop.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: In War there will always be good and evil, and it is the same amongst the followers of Iop. Their moral compass tends to be as simple as they are themselves, some evil-leaning Iops fighting for power and some good-leaning Iops fighting to protect, some chaotic-leaning Iops fighting for the thrill of it and some lawful-leaning Iops fighting to uphold the rules.

info.name: Names
entries: Most Iops have simple, short and easy to pronounce names. There are many cases nonetheless of Iops being named in a knightly manner or after weaponry.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Vald, Solar, Peggy, Rish Claymore, Goultard, Percival, Beldivere

heritage.name: Vitalized Iop
entries: Some Iops have trained to take more hits, in order to hit more. You gain 10 Hit Points from your ancestry instead of 8 and gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Athletics} checks to {@action Shove} or {@action Trip} foes.

heritage.name: Battleborn Iop
entries: Some Iops were born with a silver sword on their hand. You're trained in all simple and martial weapons. You also gain the {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz} ancestry feat.

ancestry.name: Cra
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).

features.name: Low-Light Vision
entries: You can see in dim light as though it were bright light, so you ignore the concealed condition due to dim light.

info: It's hard to tell what's going on in a Cra's head when you're not one of them, but let's just say they seem to be gifted with the innate science of the projectile. A young Cra can shoot down a Moskito with spit weighed down by sugary sweets. The meetings behind the public urinal at the Trool Fair made Cras famous (because their jets are very long, if not the longest). Cra archers can carve a projectile out of just about any material, including the rarest ones, just by following their instinct. For instance, a Treechnid branch, once carved, can be of a surprising long range. Cras' craftsmanship became renowned thanks to their bow jobs, in which they take both pride and pleasure.

Hair blowing in the wind, slender silhouette, chiselled muscle structure, chest thrown out: the Cra disciple is proud, that's for sure. They are precious allies against melee attacks. Standing back from the ruckus, they shoot their feathered arrows into any opening left unattended, and they really hurt! That's why they're so popular for hunting and combat groups, in which they are known to have saved many allies. Of course, when Cras are forced to enter close combat, they find it harder to stand their ground... but you can't have it all!

items: Prefer to distance yourself from others.
Enjoy climbing into tall places just to enjoy the view.
Carefully scout a target or problem before striking at it quickly.
Respect your incredible sight.
Worry that you privately look down on them, or feel like you're condescending and aloof.
Assume that you'll be useless in a close quarters fight.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Cra are about as tall as other average humans. Their eyes are often of a green colour, and are a Cra's joy and pride. Cras are often blonde or red-headed, with freckles sometimes adorning their face. Most Cra hairstyles are long but tied up in a variety ways (such as ponytails or braids), but some Cras may prefer to keep their hair short and simple.

Cras age at a similar rate to normal humans. Most Cras can live to be up to 80 years of age, but the more powerful Cras could live for nearly two centuries. Cras are more slender than the average human, and so tend to weigh less. The two predominant aesthetics in Cra clothing are full-body jumpsuits and skimpier tank tops with short pants or skirts, either style being often predominantly of a green or brown colour.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Cras often take on the jobs that require a good sight, such as hunters or lookouts. In particular, Cras will prefer to live in more structured and possibly hierarchical structures. All Cras may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Cras are very prideful and so may often look down upon others, such as Iops' for their simpleness, but they will respect anyone they deem can pull their own worth.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Followers of Cra tend to be of the Lawful alignment, with no real tendency towards good or evil. It is nonetheless not unheard of Cras who will fight against the establishment, such as Robbie Hoodie.

info.name: Names
entries: Most Cras have names that will roll off your tongue, often sounding elegant and exotic.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Evangelyne, Setsinbol, Robbie Hoodie, Edrige Valling, Kalisthe

heritage.name: Owl Eye Cra
entries: Your vision has adapted so even the darkest of nights cannot hinder it. You gain {@ability darkvision}.

heritage.name: Eagle Eye Cra
entries: There is nothing that your eyes cannot see, and your other senses aren't too far behind. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to locate {@condition undetected} creatures within 60 feet when using the {@action Seek} action. Your flat check to target {@condition concealed} creatures is DC {@flatDC 3} instead of DC {@flatDC 5}, and your flat check to target {@condition undetected} creatures is DC {@flatDC 9} instead of DC {@flatDC 11}.

ancestry.name: Sacrier
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).

features.name: Tattoo Mastery
entries: You can control the shape and size of any tattoo on your body. Additionally, tattoos do not automatically reduce the amount of items you can invest per day. You instead need to invest the tattoo using one action to {@action Interact} with it as per the {@action Invest an Item} action.

info: Sacriers are always on the lookout for other adventurers to fight with, even though their physical appearance doesn't always help - they're not exactly ugly... especially the girls... but they're not the best-looking class either, especially if you always trust first impressions. Meeting a Sacrier in the moonlight is an especially nerve-racking experience: his proud, muscular, sinewy silhouette, his forearms covered in a thick layer of blood, his glassy eyes gazing into yours... in short, you'd be better off on his side than against him! Fortunately for them, Sacriers have a great sense of humour. Grinning from ear to ear, a Sacri will never tire of asking you to hit him ("Go on! As hard as you can!") and is one of the rare examples of adventurers who will play the "Stop hitting yourself!" game all alone. In company, he'll delight everyone with his jokes about massacre and bloodshed, and his favourite party trick is juggling his enemies' organs. In short, he's a great guy to have around, and the perfect warrior companion!

Curious by nature, Sacriers are fascinated by anatomy. Spiteful gossips say it's actually an obsession, hence their reputation as weirdos (as admiring swollen muscles or the working of joints is pretty odd...). Sacriers are renowned for being caught poking and prodding at things and generally putting their fingers everywhere. Though their habits might seem confusing, they're very useful for the magic they practise!

They are naturally good butchers, since they have a passion for chopping meat, and gutting carcasses with their bare hands. If they embrace their spiritual path, they can become very clever soothsayers. As they do not fear blows or injuries, they are great on the front line and are very much appreciated by groups of adventurers.

items: Put other people's needs before your own.
Believe that what doesn't kill you makes you stronger.
Not mind getting your hands dirty.
Think you're creepy.
Consider you a masochist.
Entrust their lives to you.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Sacrier are varied in their physical appearance. Many are tough and muscular, able to stop a sword with their abdominals, whereas others may be slim and focus on barely dodging to turn a deadly hit into a scratch. Their eyes look completely white and their nose small, sometimes almost imperceptible. The most common hair colour amongst sacriers is a deep orange, but white hair is also common, and bandanas are a very popular accessory. A Sacrier is only slightly taller than the average human on average.

Sacriers age at a similar rate to normal humans. Most Sacriers can live to be up to 80 years of age, but the more powerful Sacriers could live for nearly two centuries. Sacriers weigh the same as normal humans of similar physiques. Sacriers also favor going topless, showcasing the blood tattoos that cover their body, notably their arms and chest, and many of them mix their blood with ink during the process to colour their tattoos black instead of red. Due to this tendency of going topless, many Sacriers have a very tanned skin colour. The clothes that they do wear tend to look ragged.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Sacriers often take on the jobs that require getting their hands dirty. All Sacriers may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Most of them will create powerful bonds with other people and decide to protect them with their life.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Despite their protective nature often leading Sacriers into the Good alignment, it is not uncommon for their love for blood or the people they've bonded with to lead into Neutral or even Evil aligned Sacriers. For this same reason, Sacreirs have no tendency towards either Chaotic or Lawful alignments.

info.name: Names
entries: Most Sacriers have short names with violent-sounding consonants.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Katar, Lupa, Edass, Saketsu, Kali, Kriss the Krass, Denn Kratz

heritage.name: Heartful Sacrier
entries: A Sacrier keeps going as long as their heart keeps pumping blood. You gain 12 Hit Points from your ancestry instead of 10. You also gain the {@feat Diehard} feat.

heritage.name: Angered Sacrier
entries: Anger can be a Sacrier's greatest drive, bringing them unparalleled power. Choose either the {@archetype Cathartic Mage|SoM|Cathartic Mage (Anger)} or the {@archetype Runelord|SoM|Runelord (Wrath)} Archetype. You gain the archetype's dedication feat, even though you don't meet its level prerequisite. You must still meet its other prerequisites to gain the feat.

ancestry.name: Eniripsa
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).
info: Whereas most adventurers cross the World with the hope of punching you in the face, the Eniripsas use their hands for something completely different: they heal the good, the bad and sometimes (actually, often) even the ugly!

With one hand on their hearts and the other cupped like a megaphone, Eniripsas base their magic on words which can heal or hurt according to their needs. Needless to say, when they open their mouths, everyone listens carefully...

Although they are often very adept at alchemy, most Eniripsa magic relies on their Words, which have become famous all around the World. Some are famous for their "good words" and others for their "bad words". Some Eniripsas even become word hunters, collecting verbs and foraging for forgotten languages. Eniripsas are often seen talking to shady and disreputable people, but they're just trying to get precious vocabulary from them...

items: Care for other people's wellbeing.
Have an interest in poisons and elixirs.
Love experimenting with anything you get your hands on.
Assume you cannot defend yourself.
Think you are too kind for your own good.
Rely greatly on your treatments.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Eniripsa tend to be small and thin. They do not have very distinctive features other than the wings on their back. Some may possess strikingly beautiful insect wings, whereas others grew dark and somber bat wings, and albeit very rare there are cases of Eniripsas with feathery wings. A normally tall Eniripsa is usually still as tall as the average human, but the shorter ones could be even just 4 feet tall.

Eniripsas age at a similar rate to normal humans. Most Eniripsas can live to be up to 80 years of age, but the more powerful Eniripsas could live for nearly two centuries. Eniripsas are lighter than a human of similar physique, but sometimes the weight of the wings can even that. Eniripsas usually wear sleeveless clothing and prefer baggy pants and short skirts. They sometimes wear detached fabric sleeves to cover their arms.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Eniripsas often take on the jobs that require tact and care. All Eniripsas may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Most of them will try to help their peers whenever they can, and have great respect for alchemists.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Due to their good faith Eniripsas are often of the Good alignment. Nonetheless Eniripsas also do not usually discriminate when it comes to helping, and may also believe that ends justify their means. Due to their experimental nature they also lean towards the Chaotic alignment.

info.name: Names
entries: Most Eniripsas have short and even sweet-sounding names.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Lily, Vax, Nabrisa, Brumen, Skeunk, Echo

heritage.name: Soothing Eniripsa
entries: Healing is a way of life. An Eniripsa must know how to treat wounds with utmost care, be it their own or anyone else's. When anyone uses the {@skill Medicine} skill to {@action Treat Wounds} you add your level to the Hit Points regained.

heritage.name: Skywalker Eniripsa
entries: Your bones are lighter and you can open your wings to slow your descent through the air. You take no damage from falling, regardless of the distance you fall.

ancestry.name: Sram
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).

features.name: Low-Light Vision
entries: You can see in dim light as though it were bright light, and you ignore the concealed condition due to dim light.

features.name: Skull Mask
entries: You gain one skull mask for free, as it was given to you at the time of your initiation as a Sram. Selling this mask is a terrible taboo and earns you the disdain of other Sram's.

info: Beware of any Srams who seem to be sending sneaky glances your way. Before you know it, you'll be stripped of your cherished belongings, especially the most expensive ones! If you only learn one thing about followers of the skull-headed god, let it be this: they love everything that dangles, especially rounded pouches... They're also always on the lookout for loose tongues, because anyone who might be a source of useful information interests them... Riffling through the tails of a tunic, feeling the bottom of a pocket, exercising their nimble fingers, and finally holding long-desired jewels in their hands are just a few of a Sram's favourite things.
Robbers, pilferers, shoplifters, snatchers, plunderers and cheaters! They are often where we don't want to see them: in bank vaults, dark alleyways and at the end of our pouch strings.

To master their art, Srams submit themselves to a severe training regime that would make mere mortals go white with fear. To be honest, when Srams first find out about it, they go white with fear too, but since they have such a pale complexion, no one notices. The neophyte's aim is to become extremely supple and to control his senses and his Chakras perfectly. Believe me, it can be really useful! Mastering this art will enable him to dislocate a joint so as to voluntarily sneak into very narrow places. Srams are not afraid of tight spaces... as long as there are kamas hidden inside. This set of secret techniques is called the Kama Sutars.

items: Enjoy the night over the day.
Feel an affinity to the undead.
Love to see someone fall into one of your traps.
Assume you are a loner.
Feel unnerved by your presence.
Respect your skills.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Sram tend to be skeletally thin, often even literally. They are either walking skeletons, wear skull masks, or simply wear predominantly bone-themed clothing. Although much lighter, a Sram is usually not taller than the average human.

Srams age at a similar rate to normal humans, although it is often not very noticeable. Most Srams live to be up to 80 years of age, but the most powerful Srams could live for nearly two centuries. Srams tend to wear either very little clothing, or a full body suit, with very little in between.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Srams often take on the jobs that require diligence and discretion. All Srams may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Most of them will do sketchy jobs, or turn to crime.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Due to their criminal tendencies Srams are often of the Chaotic alignment, but many still find their slyness of better use in more Lawful ways. Despite appearances, there is no real tendency towards Evil, and neither towards Good, but towards neutrality.

info.name: Names
entries: Srams have very varied names, often choosing a name for themselves.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Ejipe, Ogivol, Rebecca, Erazal, Oscar Kass, Gein, Toxine, Maude

heritage.name: Shadowed Sram
entries: You live in the shadows and so your sight has adapted to dark environments. You gain {@ability darkvision}.

heritage.name: Cadaverous Sram
entries: You are as light as a feather, giving you incredible agility. Your Speed increases from 25 to 30 feet.

ancestry.name: Xelor
languages: Additional languages equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier (if it's positive). Choose from the list of common languages and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).

features.name: Low-Light Vision
entries: You can see in dim light as though it were bright light, and you ignore the concealed condition due to dim light.

features.name: Skull Mask
entries: You gain one skull mask for free, as it was given to you at the time of your initiation as a Sram. Selling this mask is a terrible taboo and earns you the disdain of other Sram's.

info: Xelor's worshippers venerate everything to do with telling the time: clocks, chimes, hands and so on. They consider all timepieces to be representations of Xelor himself... although some apparently think that they are also reincarnations of their ancestors... Scholars still haven't got to the bottom of this strange group which plays with time like children play with ants and magnifying glasses. At least they don't have to worry about being on time for appointments!

Xelor disciples protect their bodies from the danger of time warps with bandages. This process is important for a number of reasons. The slightest crack between two wrappings could create a major mishap: any part of their body which is not bandaged can't travel in time at the same speed as the rest of the body! A lapse in concentration could cost them dearly. Now we know why Xelors dress so modestly! Xelors are often appreciated within groups of adventurers as they can increase their allies' ability to act.

items: Be precise about every single detail.
Always keep track of the pass of time at any moment.
Instinctively process large amounts of disparate information quickly and efficiently.
Assume you have secret knowledge about magic and technology.
Think you'll go mad at any moment.
Look to you as the expert on any matters involving time or machinery.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Followers of Xelor tend to be short. They completely cover themselves with bandages to safely practice time magic, so their physical features are hidden most of the time, but they do not have any distinguishing features under the bandages.  A normally tall Xelor is usually still as tall as the average human, but the shorter ones could be even just 4 feet tall.

Xelors age at a similar rate to normal humans, but can live longer through the use of time magic. Most Xelors can live up to 100 years of age, but the more powerful Xelors could live for various centuries. Xelors weigh the same as normal humans of similar physique. There are two predominant Xelor aesthetics, some simple, comfortable and often baggy clothes and wear big hats, whereas others prefer wearing metallic faceplates and pieces of armor.

info.name: Society
entries: Societies in the World of Twelve are highly multicultural, and in them Xelors often take on the jobs that require research and precision. All Xelors may praise their god to different degrees, but their religion does not necessarily play an important role in the society they live in. Most of them will take on investigative or quiet and peaceful jobs.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Many Xelors tend to be neutral by nature, considering the world to be just a very small part of the Krosmoz and distancing themselves from the troubles of humankind, but they are not a majority. Some Xelors may find Time to be a symbol of order and feel an affinity to the Lawful alignment, whereas others may find Time to be a symbol of unpredictability and feel an affinity to the Chaotic alignment. As for the good and evil alignments, there are many records of infamous evil Xelors, but the average Xelor has no real tendency towards each side.

info.name: Names
entries: Xelors have very varied names, sometimes very short, sometimes long and complicated.

entries.name: Sample Names
entries: Amine, Methea, Jacquemart Astron, Kya, Many, Kwartzwatch, Noximilien

heritage.name: Watcher Xelor
entries: You can easily detect and understand magical phenomena. You can cast the {@spell detect magic} cantrip as a divine innate spell at will. A cantrip is heightened to a spell level equal to half your level rounded up. In addition, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to checks to {@action Identify Magic} and to {@action Decipher Writing} of a magical nature. These skill actions typically use the {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Occultism}, or {@skill Religion} skill.

heritage.name: Studious Xelor
entries: Your magic is more connected to your mind than it is to your faith. Choose {@filter arcane|spells||Level=0|Tradition & Spell List=Arcane} or {@filter occult|spells||Level=0|Tradition & Spell List=Occult}. You gain one cantrip from that magical tradition's spell list. You can cast this spell as an innate spell at will, as a spell of your chosen tradition. A cantrip is heightened to a spell level equal to half your level rounded up. Whenever you gain a divine innate spell from a xelor ancestry feat, change its tradition from divine to your chosen tradition.

feat.name: Divine Multiarms
entries: Six arms made of blood float at your sides as your blood vessels are blessed by Sacrier's tears. For 1 minute, you gain the following benefits:

items: 20 temporary Hit Points.
You are {@condition quickened} and can use the additional action to {@action Strike}.
Your unarmed attacks deal {@damage 2d8} damage and gain the {@trait Forceful} trait.
{@skill Athletics} modifier of +23, unless your own modifier is higher.

feat.name: Bloodthirsty Madness
entries: You lash out viciously even as you fend off death. Make a single melee {@action Strike}. If this {@action Strike} brings a foe to 0 Hit Points, this activation of {@feat Sacrier Ferocity|FPKrosmoz} doesn't count against its frequency.

feat.name: Sacrier Weapon Expertise
entries: Your training with Sacrier weapons has fully paid off. Whenever you gain a class feature that grants you expert or greater proficiency in a given weapon or weapons, you also gain that proficiency in the fist unarmed attack, {@item bastard sword}, {@item tekko-kagi} and all {@filter sacrier weapons|items||Category=Weapon|Ancestry & Heritage=Sacrier} in which you are trained.

feat.name: Unfalling Ravager
entries: The impulse to survive and continue fighting resonates deep within you. You gain a circumstance bonus to damage rolls on your melee {@action Strike||Strikes} equal to twice the sum of your {@condition wounded} and {@condition doomed} conditions (to a maximum of a +8 circumstance bonus to damage) whenever you have one or both conditions.

feat.name: Bloody Avenger
feat.trigger: You are adjacent to an ally with the {@condition dying} condition.
entries: No enemy will take down one of your allies, or at least not without paying the cost. Make a {@action Strike}. Roll twice on the attack roll and use the higher result.

feat.name: Blood Tentacles
entries: The tattooed blood in your body turns into tentacles. You can cast {@spell black tentacles} once per day as an innate divine spell, though when you do so, you spew them from your arms out to the appropriate range, where they take root and begin {@action Grapple||Grappling} creatures as usual. The tentacles recognize you as a part of them and don't attempt to {@action Grapple} you, even if you are in the area.

feat.name: Undying Berserker
entries: You resist the call of Externam with supernatural vigor. When you use {@feat Sacrier Ferocity|FPKrosmoz}, you gain temporary Hit Points equal to your level.

feat.name: Punishing Comeback
entries: The more damage you receive, the stronger you become. When you are taking {@condition persistent damage} or your {@condition wounded} value is 1 or greater, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to Fortitude saving throws.

feat.name: Sacrier Magic
entries: You prioritize your allies' lives over your own and put your own body in the line. You can cast the spells {@spell Blood Vendetta} and {@spell Shield Other} once per day as 2nd-level divine innate spells.

feat.name: Goddess's Tattoos
entries: Your tattoos are a work of divine genius, a masterpiece of art, magic, and skin. Choose a 3rd-level divine spell from the same school as your {@feat Divine Tattoos|FPKrosmoz}, either a common spell or another to which you have access, including a lower-level spell heightened to 3rd level if you wish.
You can cast that spell once per day as an innate divine spell.

feat.name: Sacrier Weapon Fury
entries: You've learned to make the most advantage out of your fists and traditional weapons.

Whenever you critically hit using a fist, {@item bastard sword}, {@item tekko-kagi}, or a {@filter sacrier weapon|items||Ancestry & Heritage=sacrier|Category=Weapon}, you apply the weapon's critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Tattooed Weapon
entries: You bear tattoos enhanced by the mark of deity. When you select this feat, choose one of the options on the following page. When you critically hit using a weapon of the listed group, you apply the weapon's critical specialization effect. You gain a large tattoo.

items: {@b Axe:} {@group axe} or {@group pick}
{@b Shield:} {@group hammer} or {@group shield}
{@b Torch:} {@group bomb} or {@group knife}

feat.name: Reaching Tattoo
entries: Your tattoos empower your strikes and reach out towards your enemies. The damage die for your fist unarmed attack increases by one step until the end of your turn. In addition, the attack gains a {@trait reach} of 10 feet. This doesn't increase the reach of any unarmed attack that already has the {@trait reach} trait, but it does combine with abilities that increase your reach due to increased size, such as {@feat Giant's Stature}.

feat.name: Iron Guts
entries: Your stomach is particularly durable. When you succeed at a Fortitude save to reduce your {@condition sickened} value, you reduce it by 2 (or by 3 on a critical success).

feat.name: Empowered Tattoos
entries: You expand your tattoos to encompass greater magic. Choose a 1stâ€‘level divine spell from the same school as your {@feat Divine Tattoos|FPKrosmoz}, either a common spell or another to which you have access. You can cast that spell once per day as an innate divine spell.

feat.name: Blood Pact
entries: You're exceptionally difficult to kill. The DC of your recovery checks is equal to 9 + your dying value, or 8 + your dying value if you have the {@feat Toughness} general feat.

In addition, whenever someone returns you to life using magic that would normally leave you debilitated for a week (such as {@spell raise dead} or the {@ritual resurrect} ritual), you don't suffer that condition.

feat.name: Bloody Blows
entries: Your lethal unarmed attacks leave bloody gouges or cause severe internal bleeding. When you critically hit with a {@action Strike} using an unarmed attack that isn't {@trait nonlethal}, the target takes {@damage 1d4} {@condition persistent damage||persistent bleed damage}. This can be because you're taking the penalty to use a fist for a lethal attack or because you have an unarmed attack without the nonlethal trait due to {@feat Bloodied Fists|FPKrosmoz}, or a similar ability.

feat.name: Way of the Tattoo
entries: You search to create your own tattoos and share this Sacrier tradition with everyone. You gain the trained proficiency in {@skill Crafting}. If you were already trained in {@skill Crafting}, you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon sacrier tattoos|item||Rarity=Uncommon|Ancestry & Heritage=sacrier|Category=Tattoo}.
You gain the {@feat Tattoo Artist|SoM} feat, though when choosing your formulas for that feat, you can also choose from uncommon sacrier tattoos, as well as common tattoos.

feat.name: Sanguine Armor
entries: You reinforce the blood covering your body and become more resilient. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of your next turn.

feat.name: Sacrier Weapon Familiarity
entries: There is no weapon a Sacrier likes more than their fist, but some of them have learnt that often that isn't enough. You have the trained proficiency with the {@item bastard sword} and the {@item tekko-kagi|LOGM}.

In addition, you gain access to {@item tekko-kagi|LOGM|tekko-kagis} and all {@filter uncommon sacrier weapons|items||Category=Weapon|Rarity=Uncommon|Ancestry & Heritage=Sacrier}. For the purpose of determining your proficiency, martial sacrier weapons are simple weapons and advanced sacrier weapons are martial weapons.

feat.name: Sacrier's Blood Lore
entries: You know everything a Sacrier needs to know in life. You gain the trained proficiency in your choice of Crafting and either {@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also become trained in {@skill Lore||Sacrier Lore}.

feat.name: Sacrier Ferocity
feat.trigger: You would be reduced to 0 Hit Points but not immediately killed.
entries: Fierceness in battle runs through your blood, and you refuse to fall from your injuries. You avoid being knocked out and remain at 1 Hit Point, and your {@condition wounded} condition increases by 1.

feat.name: Penitence
feat.trigger: An ally within 30 feet gains the {@condition dying} condition.
entries: An ally falling down before you fills you with rage, gaining temporary Hit Points equal to your level for 1 minute. As long as you have these temporary Hit Points, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to attack and damage rolls.

feat.name: Divine Tattoos
entries: You have tattoos on your body blessed by the goddess Sacrier. Choose one of the following schools of magic: abjuration ({@spell shield}), conjuration ({@spell tanglefoot}), enchantment ({@spell daze}), evocation ({@spell divine lance}), illusion ({@spell bullhorn|SoM}), necromancy ({@spell chill touch}), or transmutation ({@spell sigil}). You can cast the associated cantrip (listed in parentheses) as an innate divine spell at will.

feat.name: Bloodied Fists
entries: Your fists have been forged by battle, your naturally tough skin and dense bone further hardened by conflict. Your fist unarmed attacks no longer have the {@trait nonlethal} trait and gain the {@trait grapple} weapon trait.

feat.name: Bloodied Fists
entries: Your fists have been forged by battle, your naturally tough skin and dense bone further hardened by conflict. Your fist unarmed attacks no longer have the {@trait nonlethal} trait and gain the {@trait grapple} weapon trait.

feat.name: Cra Weapon Precision
entries: You are adept at creating the Cra's beacon bomb specialty.

You gain the trained proficiency in {@skill Crafting}. If you were already trained in {@skill Crafting}, you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon beacon bombs|items||Rarity=Uncommon|Category=Bomb|Item=Beacon}.

You gain the {@feat Alchemical Crafting} skill feat. You can add {@filter uncommon 1st-level beacon|items||Rarity=Uncommon|Category=Bomb|Item=Beacon|Level=[-1;1]} formulas to your formula book in addition to the options given by the feat.

feat.name: Beacon Aficionado
entries: You are adept at creating the Cra's beacon bomb specialty.

You gain the trained proficiency in {@skill Crafting}. If you were already trained in {@skill Crafting}, you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon beacon bombs|items||Rarity=Uncommon|Category=Bomb|Item=Beacon}.

You gain the {@feat Alchemical Crafting} skill feat. You can add {@filter uncommon 1st-level beacon|items||Rarity=Uncommon|Category=Bomb|Item=Beacon|Level=[-1;1]} formulas to your formula book in addition to the options given by the feat.

feat.name: Beacon Expert
entries: Your expertise with beacons makes you able to prepare these mechanisms on a daily basis. During your daily preparations, you can create up to 3 versatile chassis that can be quickly turned into beacons. You gain the Quick Beacon action to turn one of those chassis into a beacon for which you know the formula. The number of beacons you can prepare this way increases to four if you are a master in {@skill Crafting}, and to five if you are legendary.

entries.name: Quick Beacon
entries.requirements: You know the formula for the beacon you're creating, you're holding or wearing {@item alchemist's tools}, and you have a free hand.
entries: You quickly prepare and activate your beacon, creating a single beacon of your level or lower without having to spend the normal monetary cost in alchemical reagents or needing to attempt a {@skill Crafting} check. This item has the {@trait infused} trait, but it remains potent only until the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Backline Fighter
entries: You avoid the attention of creatures focused on your allies. You can use lesser cover from your allies to {@action Hide}.

feat.name: Arrow to the Knee
entries: You attempt to hinder your enemy's movement by aiming at a precise location. Make a {@action Strike} with your ranged weapon within your first range increment.

On a hit, the target takes a –10-foot status penalty to its Speed or a –15-foot status penalty on a critical hit. This penalty applies only if the target has a land Speed and depends on legs or other targetable appendages to use its land Speed. As with all penalties to Speed, this can't reduce a creature's Speed below 5 feet.

feat.name: Reactive Sight
entries: You are always on the lookout for any danger. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Perception} checks made as initiative rolls.

feat.name: Discernful Eyes
entries: Your keen eyes can see through anything. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus on {@skill Perception} checks against illusions and you ignore concealment caused by foliage.

feat.name: Elusive Scuttle
feat.trigger: An ally ends a move action adjacent to you.
entries: You take advantage of your ally's movement to adjust your position. You {@action Step}.

feat.name: See the Unseen
entries: You notice things that others can't see at all. While you're adjacent to an {@condition undetected} creature of your level or lower, it is instead only {@condition hidden} from you. You only need a successful DC {@flatDC 5} flat check to target a {@condition hidden} creature.

feat.name: Explosive Shot
feat.trigger: You {@action Strike} a beacon with a ranged weapon
entries: You can bring beacons to their maximum potential. Any creature that fails its saving throw against the snare's initial effect critically fails instead.

feat.name: Fulminating Shot
feat.trigger: You critically hit a foe with a {@action Strike} with a ranged weapon.
entries: Your arrow calls upon the divine intervention of your deity. You Cast the {@spell Flame Strike} Spell as a 7th-level divine innate spell centered on the target of the reaction.

feat.name: Absolute Acuteness
entries: When you focus your eyes carefully, your gaze can pierce through all obfuscations, even magical ones. When you use True Gaze, you gain the effects of a 6th-level {@spell true seeing} spell, using your {@skill Perception} modifier for the counteract check.

feat.name: Ruthless Beacons
entries: You've learned how to create beacons that cause greater injuries. You deal an additional {@damage 1d6} precision damage with damaging beacons you craft.
This increases to {@damage 2d6} additional precision damage if you're legendary in {@skill Crafting}.

feat.name: Cra Weapon Expertise
entries: Training has made you an expert with Cra weapons. Whenever you gain a class feature that grants you expert or greater proficiency in a given weapon or weapons, you also gain that proficiency for the weapons from your {@feat Cra Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz}.

feat.name: Arcane Sight
feat.prerequisites: ability to cast the {@spell detect magic} cantrip
entries: You've trained yourself to constantly be on the lookout for magical effects, even when focusing on looking out for other things. When you are {@action Search||Searching}, you also gain the benefits of {@action Detect Magic} unless you choose not to.

feat.name: Terrain Advantage
entries: You can take advantage of the terrain to bypass foes' defenses. Creatures in difficult terrain are {@condition flatâ€‘footed} to you.

feat.name: Long Step
entries: You step further away from your enemies than anyone. You {@action Step} 5 feet twice.

feat.name: Cra Magic
entries: You channel the magic of Cra's Bow. You can cast {@spell acid arrow} and {@spell spirit sense} each once per day as 2nd-level divine innate spells.

feat.name: Arrow Beacon
entries: You shoot down a foe with a beacon as a gift. Make a {@action Strike} with a Ranged Attack, as part of the {@action Strike} you also Throw and {@action Activate an Item||Activate} a beacon centered on the target.

feat.name: Advanced Scuttle
entries: You can scuttle farther and faster when maneuvering alongside allies. When you use {@feat Elusive Scuttle|FPKrosmoz}, you can {@action Stride} up to half your Speed instead of {@action Step||Stepping}.

feat.name: Roly-Poly
entries: A Cra always keeps their distance, as much as your enemies will try to keep you close. When you roll a success at an {@action Escape} check, you can {@action Step} up to 5 feet.

feat.name: Locate Weak Points
entries: You can enhance your senses and mental state to know exactly where to strike. You can cast {@spell true strike} as a divine innate spell once per day.

feat.name: Divine Archery
entries: Cra guides you and grants you some of her magic. You can cast the {@spell guidance} and {@spell divine lance} as divine innate cantrips at will. A cantrip is heightened to a spell level equal to half your level rounded up.

feat.name: Cra Weapon Familiarity
entries: You favor bows of all kinds above all weapons. You are trained in all common weapons from the {@group bow} group.
In addition, you gain access to all {@filter uncommon cra weapons|items||Category=Weapon|Rarity=Uncommon|Ancestry & Heritage=Cra}.
For the purpose of determining your proficiency, martial cra weapons are simple weapons and advanced cra weapons are martial weapons.

feat.name: Cra's Range Lore
entries: You've been brought up to know everything a Cra should ever know. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Crafting} and {@skill Society}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also become trained in {@skill Lore||Cra Lore}.

feat.name: Iop's Heart Lore
entries: You have lived the life that Iop intended, following all of his tenets. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Athletics} and {@skill Intimidation}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also become trained in {@skill Lore||Iop Lore}.

feat.name: Iop Weapon Familiarity
entries: You favor swords above all weapons. You gain access to {@item Aldori Dueling Sword|LOWG|Aldori Dueling Swords}. Additionally, choose two weapons from the {@group sword} group. You can choose from among all {@filter common martial swords|items||rarity=common|group=sword|weapon/armor category=martial}, plus the {@item katana}, {@item temple sword}, and {@item wakizashi|apg}. For the purpose of determining your proficiency, that weapon is a simple weapon, and if the weapon isn't common, you gain access to it. If you are trained in all martial weapons, you add common advanced swords to the swords you can choose from.

You also gain access to all {@filter uncommon iop weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=iop}. For the purpose of determining your proficiency, martial Iop weapons are simple weapons, and advanced Iop weapons are martial weapons.

feat.name: Irrepressible
entries: An Iop never backs down from a challenge, always putting their head in the wolf's mouth. When you roll a success on a save against an {@trait emotion} or {@trait fear} effect, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Overlooked Mastermind
entries: You are not as simple as your brethren appear to be. You like to use your head sometimes, and not just in a literal way, but other people don't need to know that. You are trained in {@skill Deception} (or another skill of your choice if you were already trained in {@skill Deception}), and you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Deception} checks to {@action Lie} when specifically claiming ignorance and to {@skill Deception} DCs against {@action Sense Motive} checks to uncover such lies.

feat.name: Unburdened Iron
entries: Armour is an essential part of war, and so you have learnt to wear them like any lighter kind of clothing. Ignore the reduction to your Speed from any armor you wear.
In addition, any time you're taking a penalty to your Speed from some other reason (such as from the {@condition encumbered} condition or from a spell), deduct 5 feet from the penalty.

For example, the {@condition encumbered} condition normally gives a –10-foot penalty to Speed, but it gives you only a –5-foot penalty. If your Speed is taking multiple penalties, pick only one penalty to reduce.

feat.name: Unconventional Weaponry
entries: There is no weapon that an Iop cannot make use of. Choose an uncommon simple or martial weapon with a trait corresponding to an ancestry or that is common in another culture. You gain access to that weapon, and for the purpose of determining your proficiency, that weapon is a simple weapon.

If you are trained in all martial weapons, you can choose an uncommon advanced weapon with such a trait. You gain access to that weapon, and for the purpose of determining your proficiency, that weapon is a martial weapon.

feat.name: Cornered Fury
entries: When fighting against the odds, you never give up. If a foe of a larger size than you critically hits and damages you, that foe is {@condition flat-footed} to you for 1 round.

feat.name: Iop Weapon Fervour
entries: You've learned techniques for using blades and other iop weapons. Whenever you critically hit using one of the weapons from your {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz}, you apply the weapon's critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Defiance Unto Death
entries: Iops tend to be simple of mind but that does not make them necessarily more susceptible to mind magic. Some of them will fight against any kind of mental manipulation with everything they have. If you would start your turn {@condition confused}, {@condition controlled}, or {@condition fleeing} due to a failed Will save, you can attempt a Will save against the same DC; on a success, you become {@condition paralyzed} until your next turn, rather than act against your will.

feat.name: Martial Experience
entries: You've crossed blades with a wide variety of foes wielding a wide variety of weapons, and you've learned the basics of fighting with nearly any of them. When wielding a weapon you aren't proficient with, treat your level as your proficiency bonus.
At 11th level, you become trained in all weapons.

feat.name: Victorious Vigor
feat.trigger: You bring a foe to 0 Hit Points.
entries: Your victories in battle fill you with pride and imbue you with the energy to fight a bit longer despite your wounds.
You gain temporary Hit Points equal to your Constitution modifier until the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Battleforger
entries: You can sharpen weapons, polish armor, and apply special techniques to temporarily gain better effects from your armaments. By spending 1 hour working on a weapon or armor, you can grant it the effects of a +1 potency rune until your next daily preparations, gaining a +1 item bonus to attack rolls for a weapon or increasing armor's item bonus to AC by 1. This has no effect if the weapon or armor already had a potency rune.

feat.name: Glory And Valor!
entries: You are a follower of Iop, The Lord of the Brave. You call upon your god with a mighty cry that fills you with a revitalizing energy for 1 minute or until you critically fail a {@action Strike}, whichever comes first. For the duration, the first time each round you successfully {@action Strike} a creature of your level or higher, you regain Hit Points equal to half your level.

feat.name: Heroes' Call
entries: The songs of ancient heroes echo through your mind and quicken your pulse, especially in dire straits. You gain {@spell heroism} as a 3rd-level innate divine spell that you can cast once per day. If you {@action Cast a Spell||Cast the Spell} when you have half or fewer Hit Points, you also gain temporary Hit Points equal to twice your level.

feat.name: Iop Magic
entries: You channel the magic of Iop's Sword. You can cast {@spell Spiritual Weapon} and {@spell Instant Armor} each once per day as 2nd-level divine innate spells.

feat.name: Iop Sword Training
entries: An Iop needs to know to fend for themselves with whichever weapon they have at hand. You can change any of the swords designated in your {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz} to different swords that meet the same specifications. You have to practice with a sword during your daily preparations to designate it, and the designation only lasts until your next daily preparations. This changes only your proficiency; it doesn't change your access.

feat.name: Can't Fall Here
feat.trigger: An adjacent and willing ally would be reduced to 0 HP but not killed.
entries: You physically help an ally remain standing and encourage them to push through their pain against dire odds. Your ally doesn't fall {@condition unconscious} and remains at 1 Hit Point. The ally also gains a number of temporary Hit Points equal to your level that last for 1 minute. Fighting onward with such an injury isn't without consequence; your ally's {@condition wounded} condition increases by 1.

feat.name: Iop Sword Mastery
entries: All swords are just an extension of your soul. You change one of the swords designated in your {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz} to a new one that you're wielding, provided the sword meets the specifications of {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz}. You can {@action Interact} to draw a sword as part of this activity, designating the sword as part of drawing it; disrupting that {@action Interact} action prevents you from designating it as one of your swords. This designation lasts until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Iop Weapon Expertise
entries: Training has made you an expert with Iop weapons. Whenever you gain a class feature that grants you expert or greater proficiency in a given weapon or weapons, you also gain that proficiency for the weapons from your {@feat Iop Weapon Familiarity|FPKrosmoz}.

feat.name: Unconventional Expertise
feat.prerequisites: {@feat Unconventional Weaponry|FPKrosmoz}, trained in the weapon you chose for Unconventional Weaponry
entries: You've continued to advance your powers using your unconventional weapon. Whenever you gain a class feature that grants you expert or greater proficiency in certain weapons, you also gain that proficiency in the weapon you chose for {@feat Unconventional Weaponry|FPKrosmoz}.

feat.name: Heroic Presence
entries: The blood of heroes courses through your veins, and you inspire your allies to dig deep and find a new level of resolve. You grant up to 10 willing creatures within 30 feet the effects of a 6th-level {@spell zealous conviction}, though the effect automatically ends on a target if you give that target a command they would normally find repugnant. This action has the {@trait auditory} trait or {@trait visual} trait, depending on how you inspire your allies.

feat.name: Reckless Abandon
entries: Despite a lifetime filled with questionable decisions, you've managed to survive, as though you have uncanny luck that lets you avoid the consequences of your own actions. For the remainder of your turn, if you roll a failure or critical failure on a saving throw against a harmful effect, you get a success instead. Further, enemies and hazards that would damage you this turn roll the minimum possible damage.

These benefits apply only to harmful effects incurred entirely during your turn in which you activate Reckless Abandon, such as running through a {@spell prismatic wall}. Persistent damage and conditions that were applied prior to your turn proceed normally, and as soon as your turn ends you are subject to the full consequences of any dangers still threatening you.
